title: Synthetic Recap
body:
BOSTON – In a clash of titans at the old Boston Garden, the Houston Rockets were not defeated by the Celtics, but by a force of nature wearing green and white. Paul Pierce, in just his rookie season, authored a performance for the ages, exploding for a game-high 46 points to power the Celtics to a 107-96 victory in 1998.

While Hakeem Olajuwon provided a formidable 22 points and 15 rebounds for the Rockets, and Charles Barkley added a gritty 20-point, 10-rebound double-double, they were mere supporting actors in the Pierce showcase. The rookie from Kansas was simply unguardable, pouring in points from every conceivable angle against a defense that had no answer.

The Celtics, led by Antoine Walker’s 21 points and Kenny Anderson’s 14, wisely fed the hot hand, watching as Pierce dismantled one of the league’s most respected teams. His 46 points were not just a career-high; they were a declaration, a seismic announcement that a new superstar had arrived on the NBA landscape.

The final score, 107-96, tells a story of a comfortable Boston win, but the true narrative was Pierce’s historic night. In a building steeped in basketball legend, a new chapter was written by a rookie who played with the poise and fury of a veteran, single-handedly carrying his team to a statement victory and forever etching his name into Celtics lore.
